rubricNotes: Multi-answer questions are assessed with one rubric entry per expected point (e.g., 3 responsibilities = 3 rubric rows).

ASSESSMENTS.title: Learner Self-Reflection 1 – 24354 (v3)
ASSESSMENTS.subtitle: Demonstrate knowledge of health and safety legislation and apply safe working practices in a BCATS environment

questions.text: 1. What legislation covers the safety of people in the workplace?
questions.hint: take the legislation name from the heading/intro. (See p. 9–10)

questions.text: 2. What is the definition of a hazard?
questions.hint: Use the Glossary definition for “Hazard”. (See p. 6)

questions.text: 3. List 2 methods used to identify hazards in the workplace.
questions.hint: Use the “Identifying hazards” section and list two methods mentioned there. (See p. 13–14)

questions.text: 4. Once a hazard has been identified, what are the employer’s responsibilities?
questions.hint: Use the PCBU/employer responsibilities in the Act overview and the hazard management section (controls, information, training, emergency procedures). (See p. 9–11 and p. 13)

questions.text: 5. List 3 health and safety responsibilities of any worker/student.
questions.hint: Use the list under “What it means for you” and choose three responsibilities from that section. (See p. 11)

questions.text: 6. Before you enter a workplace your employer is obliged to provide you with specific safety information. List 4 types of information that would ensure they meet this requirement.
questions.hint: Use the section describing what a PCBU must provide before you enter/work in a workplace. (See p. 10)

questions.text: 7. Where do you get information on the toxicity of the materials that you are working with?
questions.hint: Use the “Chemicals” section and identify where toxicity/hazard information is found for products. (See p. 37 and p. 41)

questions.text:
i) You are preparing to use a portable power planer to skim the side off a door. You have left your safety glasses in the workshop. It will take you half an hour to go back and get them. The job will only take 10 minutes to complete.

a. identify the potential hazards
questions.hint: Identify hazards that relate specifically to not wearing eye protection when using the planer (e.g., flying chips/dust causing eye injury). (See p. 17–19)

questions.text:
i) You are preparing to use a portable power planer to skim the side off a door. You have left your safety glasses in the workshop. It will take you half an hour to go back and get them. The job will only take 10 minutes to complete.

b. assess the level of risk and describe any potential consequences or harm
questions.hint: Describe how likely harm is AND how bad it could be. Include consequences (especially to eyes) and use risk language (high/medium/low or likely/unlikely). (See p. 15 and p. 17–19)

questions.text:
i) You are preparing to use a portable power planer to skim the side off a door. You have left your safety glasses in the workshop. It will take you half an hour to go back and get them. The job will only take 10 minutes to complete.

c. describe the appropriate course of action for managing the risk.
questions.hint: Explain what you should do to manage the risk (don’t start until you have eye protection). Use the hierarchy of controls + PPE requirements. (See p. 15–16 and p. 17–19)

questions.text:
ii) During your first week on the job you have been told to use the circular saw bench to rip some lengths of timber into strips. You have never used a circular saw before or been given any instruction about the correct operating procedures for one.

a. identify the potential hazards
questions.hint: Identify hazards related to using a circular saw bench without training/instructions (e.g., kickback, exposed blade, hands too close, lack of guarding/push stick). (See p. 28–29 and p. 10–12)

questions.text:
ii) During your first week on the job you have been told to use the circular saw bench to rip some lengths of timber into strips. You have never used a circular saw before or been given any instruction about the correct operating procedures for one.

b. assess the level of risk and describe any potential consequences or harm
questions.hint: State the risk level (high/medium/low) and explain what could happen (e.g., serious cuts, amputation, kickback injury). Mention why it is risky (untrained + sharp blade). (See p. 15–16 and p. 28–29)

questions.text:
ii) During your first week on the job you have been told to use the circular saw bench to rip some lengths of timber into strips. You have never used a circular saw before or been given any instruction about the correct operating procedures for one.

c. describe the appropriate course of action for managing the risk.
questions.hint: Use the section about what to do if you’re not trained/competent and the machine safety rules (guards, procedures, supervision). (See p. 12 and p. 28–29)

questions.text:
ii) During your first week on the job you have been told to use the circular saw bench to rip some lengths of timber into strips. You have never used a circular saw before or been given any instruction about the correct operating procedures for one.

c. describe the appropriate course of action for managing the risk.
questions.hint: Say you should NOT use the saw until trained. Tell your supervisor/teacher and ask for instruction or supervision. Mention safe setup (guards on, push stick, PPE). (See p. 12 and p. 28–29)

questions.text:
iii) The body of the electric drill is cracked. Some of the wires are exposed but none of them appear to be damaged.

b. assess the level of risk and describe any potential consequences or harm
questions.hint: State the risk level (likely high) and describe consequences such as electric shock/burns or even fire. (See p. 15 and p. 34)

questions.text:
iii) The body of the electric drill is cracked. Some of the wires are exposed but none of them appear to be damaged.

c. describe the appropriate course of action for managing the risk.
questions.hint: Do not use the drill. Unplug/turn off and remove it from use. Tag it out or isolate it, then report it so it can be repaired or replaced. (See p. 28–29 and p. 34)

questions.text:
iv) You are using the spindle moulder to shape some short lengths of timber. The guards are getting in the way. One of your workmates suggests removing them until you complete this job.

a. identify the potential hazards
questions.hint: Think: removing guards exposes a rotating cutter. What harm could happen to hands/fingers or from flying material? (See p. 28–29)

questions.text:
iv) You are using the spindle moulder to shape some short lengths of timber. The guards are getting in the way. One of your workmates suggests removing them until you complete this job.

b. assess the level of risk and describe any potential consequences or harm
questions.hint: Think: without guards the rotating cutter is exposed. How likely is injury, and how serious could it be? (See p. 15–16 and p. 28–29)

questions.text:
iv) You are using the spindle moulder to shape some short lengths of timber. The guards are getting in the way. One of your workmates suggests removing them until you complete this job.

c. describe the appropriate course of action for managing the risk.
questions.hint: You must keep guards in place. Use safe methods for short timber (jigs/push tools/clamps) and get supervision if unsure. (See p. 11 and p. 28–29)

questions.text:
v) You are in the process of delivering a finished set of chairs to a customer. As you unload the truck you notice that one of the chair legs is made of cross-grained timber.

a. identify the potential hazards
questions.hint: Identify what could go wrong and who could be harmed (e.g., weak timber → chair leg could fail → customer could fall). (See p. 6 and p. 15)

questions.text:
v) You are in the process of delivering a finished set of chairs to a customer. As you unload the truck you notice that one of the chair legs is made of cross-grained timber.

b. assess the level of risk and describe any potential consequences or harm
questions.hint: Describe what could happen, how likely it is, and how bad the outcome could be (e.g., chair leg could fail → customer could fall → broken bones). (See p. 15)

questions.text:
v) You are in the process of delivering a finished set of chairs to a customer. As you unload the truck you notice that one of the chair legs is made of cross-grained timber.

c. describe the appropriate course of action for managing the risk.
questions.hint: Explain what you should do immediately, how you would fix it, and what you would do to prevent it happening again. (See p. 15–16)

questions.text:
vi) You have just spilt some oil on the workshop floor; it is the end of the day and you plan to clean it up tomorrow.

a. identify the potential hazards
questions.hint: Use the “Your work area” section on keeping the workspace tidy and safe (including spill hazards). (See p. 28)

questions.text:
vi) You have just spilt some oil on the workshop floor; it is the end of the day and you plan to clean it up tomorrow.

b. assess the level of risk and describe any potential consequences or harm
questions.hint: Use the “Assessing risk” section (likelihood + severity) and consider typical injury outcomes from slips/falls. (See p. 15, plus first aid examples p. 38)

questions.text:
vi) You have just spilt some oil on the workshop floor; it is the end of the day and you plan to clean it up tomorrow.

c. describe the appropriate course of action for managing the risk.
questions.hint: Use the “Your work area” section for controls/actions to prevent slips and protect others until the hazard is removed. (See p. 28)

ASSESSMENTS.title: Learner Self-Reflection 2 – 24354 (v3)
ASSESSMENTS.subtitle: Demonstrate knowledge of health and safety legislation and apply safe working practices in a BCATS environment

questions.text: 1. You are required to unload 15 x 40kg bags of cement off the back of a truck. The storage area is 75 metres away across a drive littered with construction waste. Describe the safest and most efficient means to get the cement into the storage area.
questions.hint: Think: make the route safe, use a trolley/wheelbarrow or mechanical aid, get help, and avoid carrying too much at once. (See p. 30–31)

questions.text: 2. Describe the correct lifting techniques for a heavy load, such as a bag of cement.
questions.hint: Think: knees bent, straight back, keep it close, no twisting, lift with legs. (See p. 31)

questions.text: 3. Describe the correct technique for carrying a sheet of plywood.
questions.hint: Think: two people, carry on edge, communicate, and make sure you can see where you are going. (See p. 30)

questions.text: 4. Identify a risk associated with storing heavy items on shelves.
questions.hint: Think: heavy items can fall or overload shelves and hurt someone. (See p. 31)

questions.text: 5a. Identify the type of fire extinguisher you would use, what type of fire it is for, and give an example of a combustible material.
questions.hint: Choose one extinguisher (e.g., Water, CO2, Foam, Powder, Wet Chemical) and match it to what it is used on + an example material. (See p. 41)

questions.text: 5b. Identify a DIFFERENT type of fire extinguisher you would use, what type of fire it is for, and give an example of a combustible material.
questions.hint: Choose a different extinguisher from 5a (e.g., Water, CO2, Foam, Powder, Wet Chemical) and match it to what it is used on + an example material. (See p. 41)

questions.text: 6. Describe the potential consequences of using a water type extinguisher on an electrical fire.
questions.hint: Think: water conducts electricity → electric shock or electrocution. (See p. 41)

questions.text: 7. What does the sign to the right represent and when would this area be used?
questions.hint: What is the name of this place and when do people go there? Think: emergencies/evacuation. (See p. 39–40)

ASSESSMENTS.title: Learner Self-Reflection 3 – 24354 (v3)
ASSESSMENTS.subtitle: Demonstrate knowledge of health and safety legislation and apply safe working practices in a BCATS environment

questions.text: 1. Your first job involves working on a roof. You feel uncomfortable at heights. What should you do?
questions.hint: Use the section about speaking up if you are worried and what to do if work feels unsafe. (See p. 12)

questions.text: 2. What is the recommended angle ratio for a ladder when it is set up?
questions.hint: Use the ladder setup diagram/ladder safety section and state the recommended setup ratio/angle. (See p. 32–33)

questions.text: 3. Why are power lines an extreme hazard when you are carrying or using an aluminium ladder?
questions.hint: Use the ladder safety section about overhead wires and the electrical safety section about electrical hazards. (See p. 33–34)

questions.text: 4. What is the minimum distance the top of a ladder should extend above a working platform?
questions.hint: Use the ladder safety rules and state the minimum extension above the landing/platform. (See p. 33)

questions.text: 5. Identify the possible consequences of directing compressed air at another person.
questions.hint: Use the “Compressed air” section and list the consequences described there. (See p. 34–35)

questions.text: 7. Identify 3 potential hazards and ongoing consequences that could occur if you decide to use a machine without receiving instructions in its proper use.
questions.hint: Use the tools/equipment/machinery section describing unsafe conditions (e.g., missing guards/faulty wiring/defective switches) and what happens if machines are misused. (See p. 28–29)
